posts.name: Meteor0id
posts.cooked:
Today a Dutch news program (nieuwsuur) asks the question: if big tech is facing new regulation, what kind of regulation would help solve problems?

The organisation they turn to for answers is a Dutch non-profit called Bits of Freedom. Their spokesperson Lotje Beek brings up the solution of legally forcing messaging apps to be interoperatable: someone using Signal should be able to message someone on WhatsApp and vise versa so no one is still stuck using any messenger app just because everyone is on it.

On one hand that would be great, as it would take away any reason to stay on apps like Whatsapp for anything else than handy features or prettier stickers. Apps such as Signal would for sure gain much popularity.

However how could that possibly work? How could Signal be Signal if they are forced to make dure their messages can also be send to WhatsApp? How can end-to-end encryption still work reliably between different apps of different companies, one of which collects metadata and the other open sources the server code?

When I read that article I got a little concerned, this doesn‚Äôt at all sound like a feasable solution, yet this comes from Bots of Freedom, an organisation with a lot of media attention, and who are occasionslly asked by parlement to advise on digital rights matters. If this is the best we can come up that maybe no one knows the solution yet?

Would interoperability even be feasable?

Got a link to that? I‚Äôd like to see it.

Also, perhaps you need to fix some typos, I especially don‚Äôt know what ‚Äúdore tly‚Äù means .

If WhatsApp is still using Signal protocol, interoperability and maintaining E2EE isn‚Äôt a big problem for some aspects. Both clients can decrypt each other‚Äôs messages. Of course, metadata will be leaked if a Signal user contacts a WhatsApp user.

With some standardization on how the decrypted messages are structured, simple text messages, receipts, typing indicators, attachments can be exchanged.

Groups can be problematic and WhatsApp is unlikely to change it because they use the metadata for more things than just ads.

Direct calls might also require lot of changes.

This seems to be little Sci-Fi, but this idea can be present of future (in future) .

This may not come first for E2EE, but will.

I had also came across this idea once in past.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
It will mean that the basic demands are designed by committee, never change in practice and leak all kinds of data. Proper encryption will not be part of the standard because governments don‚Äôt like that. So it will become quite less secure for Signal users.

In practice it will kick all messenger companies that have a presence in the EU out of it, and the rest will give the Eurocrats the finger and say that if the EU wants to enforce its laws outside its own territory they need an army willing to invade others. It might work out well for the Brittish IT sector if they keep their anti-encryption stance down.

If they want everyone able to use a shared technology they should make a law that makes sms free of charge. The high costs of sms here was the main reason WhatsApp became so big here.

Isn‚Äôt Signal Protocol already used by many? Signal, WhatsApp, Skype, Matrix, some dead Google project. Are there others?

Would it be so bad to have/force basic one on one text message interoperability with these?

I‚Äôm sorry to ask that, but what will be the benefit for Signal ?
Users will download Signal less and the donation would also go down

The encryption protocol is the same but the message protocol isn‚Äôt.
You can use a wide variety of protocols with TLS. The encryption is the same but the communication isn‚Äôt.
Different layers‚Ä¶

Forcing a standard would put us back into the time of E-Mail. Nothing would evolve as everyone has their own mind to go.

Luc4s:

what will be the benefit

WhatsApp is used by most people where I live. For the one off conversations, it would be more useful to have interoperability. You are guaranteed encryption of content and what would leak is little compared to directly using WhatsApp. I would not use this option for close and frequent contacts.

Leptopoda:

the message protocol isn‚Äôt.

I was only talking about basic texts. It doesn‚Äôt require much standardization and there is nothing there to innovate.

newuser:

WhatsApp is used by most people where I live.

Yes, it‚Äôs the benefit for the user. But how could it be advantageous for Signal company?

Signal‚Äôs biggest problem is the network effect. People don‚Äôt use it because they don‚Äôt know anyone using it. This happens even after waves of new users. A few contacts from the Jan wave removed Signal soon afterwards.

Maybe more people will drop whatsapp or reduce usage of the app because being able to exchange basic text messages would be enough for them. I know a couple people like this. Anything which reduces of usage of closed source/data collecting appss should be considered a win for Signal.
The nasty thing about bridges is that typically they allow traffic in two directions‚Ä¶

Meteor0id:

‚Ä¶ Dutch non-profit called Bits of Freedom. Their spokesperson Lotje Beek brings up the solution of legally forcing messaging apps to be interoperatable: someone using Signal should be able to message someone on WhatsApp and vise versa ‚Ä¶

what a nightmare!!! So, I should ‚Äúvoluntarily‚Äù feed them with metadata as well?
There are already ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù for this: SMS, e-mail.
I‚Äôm surprised to hear such a proposal from such an organization.

posts.name: üëäüá∫üá∏üî•
posts.cooked:
There are many problems with this:

  1. Signal, an open-source app, would be interoperable with WhatsApp, a closed-source app developed by a company notorious for caring very little for user security and privacy, and as has been recently publicly disclosed (though known for years), user health and well-being.

  2. Signal would need more resources (money and employees) to maintain this functionality.

  3. This would probably open up Signal to governmental pressure to implement logging that would put the information they can provide when subpoenaed in parity with WhatsApp, which nobody that is privacy-conscious wants.

  4. Would interoperability compromise Signal in a way that if another Facebook outage happens like the other day, could it also break Signal?

  5. What would Signal get out of such a partnership, and would Signal even want it? It seems antithetical to their mission.

Many others, but someone else can probably add.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
newuser:

You are guaranteed encryption of content and what would leak is little compared to directly using WhatsApp.

Not really. For example, sealed sender is, AFAIK, something only Signal has implemented and that is important IMO now that not only FB but also governments are taking an interest in that data.

newuser:

it would be more useful to have interoperability

Would you consider this akin to the SMS message option in the android version of the Signal app?

Leptopoda:

The encryption protocol is the same but the message protocol isn‚Äôt.

What data does Signal send to the receiving device when you message, and (hypothetically) how much would it send if you sent a message from Signal to Whatsapp?

anon53652:
newuser:

You are guaranteed encryption of content and what would leak is little compared to directly using WhatsApp.

Not really. For example, sealed sender is, AFAIK, something only Signal has implemented

I was not comparing Signal with Whatsapp. This is the scenario I was talking about: say you need to contact someone who only uses whatsapp and the need to contact is at your end and not theirs. Would you want to call or send them SMS rather than using a Signal-WhatsApp bridge? I can obtain voip numbers and use VPN and minimize the info the whatsapp network gets.

Regarding sealed sender, it is broken in many ways. The server can easily learn who is talking with whom and with SenderKeys it also knows about group membership. Signal is more trustworthy than anything Zuckerberg runs, but let‚Äôs not be under the assumption that they can‚Äôt give more data to the US govt, maybe under duress and a gag order.

Blue42:
newuser:

it would be more useful to have interoperability

Would you consider this akin to the SMS message option in the android version of the Signal app?

Yes, good point. However, SMS is one of the worst ways to communicate. RCS is supposed to be E2EE. Maybe if it becomes available everywhere and free of cost, it would be of similar use as a whatsapp bridge.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
newuser:

This is the scenario I was talking about: say you need to contact someone who only uses whatsapp and the need to contact is at your end and not theirs. Would you want to call or send them SMS rather than using a Signal-WhatsApp bridge?

I would use WhatsApp, that I have already installed anyway. Sms are not free here, I use that only as a last resort backup if internet is not available.

anon53652:

I would use WhatsApp, that I have already installed anyway.

And since I haven‚Äôt, it would be great if there is interoperability. Just like you can send SMS, if you can send that same content E2EE no matter what app is being used at the other end.

posts.name: anon53652
posts.cooked:
newuser:

Just like you can send SMS, if you can send that same content E2EE no matter what app is being used at the other end.

Optimist. If politicians make such rules it will probably result in Signal being forced to implement a non-encrypted interoperability format so they can snoop it for wrongthink.
